This is such an interesting exploration of the capability of objects (and the act of curation) to unsettle, intervene and disturb. It shows how different eyes can draw different narratives from collections. It brings things to life and is very exciting. ðŸŒ‘

The catalogue also directly addresses the â€˜discomfortâ€™ of de Waal working with the Kunsthistorisches Museum - an institution that directly gained from the loss of his own and other Jewish families, when their art collection were stolen by the Nazis and repurposed elsewhere.

The exhibition dwelt on the anxiety & emotions inherent in objects & artworks. Postcards of the DÃ¼rer sketch and the devil floating in glass have sat on my desk throughout writing my thesis to remind me that objects are not always what they seem at first glance.

I havenâ€™t stopped thinking about Edmund de Waalâ€™s â€˜During the Nightâ€™ exhibition since I saw it at the Kunsthistorisches Museum Wien 3 years ago. So thrilled to finally own the catalogue, which is really more like a printed version of the exhibition. ðŸŒ‘ https://t.co/FAXVerUxlp
